Description: Wooden stool with lattice bracing, gessoed and painted white. The double-cove seat is formed of curved strips of wood with four slats in the centre. The wood was either steamed and bent or cut to shape. The surface has been gessoed and painted white. Lattice bracing fills the voids between the four legs of the stool. The sides alternate in the use of one and two vertical struts, one for the shorter sides and two for the longer. A feature common in latticework stools is the slightly higher stretchers on the shorter sides, which preserves the strength of the wood by separating pairs of mortise-and-tenon joints.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: H. S. Baker, 'Furniture in the Ancient World' (London, 1966),, p.134, fig.192; P. De Bruyne, 'Vorm en Geometrie in de Oud-Egyptische meubelkunst' (Ghent, 1982), p. 20-5, 84-95 [8]; G. Killen, 'Egyptian Woodworking and Furniture' (Prices Risborough, 1994), p.45, pl.52; Namur, 'Les amour d'une princesse égyptienne' (alternate title, 'Le Roman de la Momie'), (Saint-Gérard, 1997), p.128 [120]. Egypt's Golden Age (exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982): 71-2, no.42
For other examples of lattice stools, see Killen, Ancient Egyptian Furniture I (1980), 46-8 [includes references to depictions in 18th dynasty tombs at Thebes]
Bibliographic references: Museum of Fine Arts Boston 1982 / Egypt's Golden Age: The Art of Living in the New Kingdom 1558-1085 BC (42)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1982 Feb-May, Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Egypt's Golden Age 1982 Jul-Sep, Houston, Houston Museum of Natural Science, Egypt's Golden Age 1982/3 Oct-Jan, Baltimore, Walters Art Gallery, Egypt's Golden Age 1997 May-Oct, Abbaye Saint-Gerard De Brogne, Le Roman de la momie 1998/9 Oct-Jun, South Carolina, The Charleston Museum, Queens Commoners of the New Kingdom 2001 26 Jun-23 Sep, Birmingham Gas Hall, Egypt Revealed
